item.description:
Paul Thomas Anderson's newest film is not based on the life of L. Ron Hubbard.

After returning from the Second World War, and having witnessed many horrors, a charismatic intellectual, Lancaster Dodd (Philip Seymour Hoffman), creates a faith-based organization in an attempt to provide meaning to his now landlocked life. His teachings gather a devout following and he becomes known as "The Master". His right-hand man Freddie Sutton (Joaquin Phoenix), a former drifter and bad boy sailor, begins to question both the belief system and The Master himself.

David Poland, MCN Blogs:

"It’s been the oddest thing. Lots of critics have now seen The Master, yet there seems to be almost no deep conversation about it. And the couple of pieces I have found have been written with such flowery, non-specific language (regarding intent, not the story) that it feels very, very safe.

So tonight, I saw it… the way it should be seen. In 70mm, yes, but more so, in a big theater, full of people.They were literally wrapped around the block for this sold-out engagement."

 

Please note the phrase 'Sold-Out".  Get your tickets ASAP, or you may be shut out from seeing this showing: tickets

Rating: 5.0/5.0

By BRIAN TALLERICO

I’ve been also been wondering if its two amazing stars – Joaquin Phoenix and Philip Seymour Hoffman – have ever given better performances... the recurring theme in my many thoughts and conversations about one of the most remarkable film-going events of my life has been this – Paul Thomas Anderson may be the most ambitious filmmaker working today...Viewers will find different themes and have different responses. I’m looking forward to a second viewing to fine tune my own. “The Master” is that kind of film, one that works its way into your brain and forces you to consider its themes for days, weeks, or months after you see it until you simply have to see it again."

This may become one of this group's best post-film discussions since No Country for Old Men or Paul Anderson's own There Will Be Blood.  Certain to be controversial and filled with multiple interpretations, there aren't many cinematic experiences that lend itself to both dialog and a need for a second viewing!  If you plan to attend, get your ticket ahead of time as early as you can.  I hope it doesn't sell-out minutes after tickets are available.

If you (and I) do get a ticket, I'll see you at the movies!

John
item.how_to_find_us: John will be in the lobby following the film holding an authentically original Meetup Sign to guide the group to a nearby eatery depending on the size of the group for scintillating discussion
item.name: The Master
